At that time, the Jewel Girl again addressed the Buddha, saying:

translated: They understand that due to the condition of ignorance, there are karmic formations; due to the condition of karmic formations, there is consciousness; due to the condition of consciousness, there is name-and-form; due to the condition of name-and-form, there are the six sense bases; due to the condition of the six sense bases, there is contact; due to the condition of contact, there is feeling; due to the condition of feeling, there is craving; due to the condition of craving, there is grasping; due to the condition of grasping, there is becoming; due to the condition of becoming, there is birth; due to the condition of birth, there is old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress;

Because of the cessation of ignorance, formations cease. Because of the cessation of formations, consciousness ceases. Because of the cessation of consciousness, name-and-form ceases. Because of the cessation of name-and-form, the six sense bases cease. Because of the cessation of the six sense bases, contact ceases. Because of the cessation of contact, feeling ceases. Because of the cessation of feeling, craving ceases. Because of the cessation of craving, clinging ceases. Because of the cessation of clinging, existence ceases. Because of the cessation of existence, birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress cease. Thus does the great mass of suffering cease.
Having contemplated in this way, he further thinks:
'These dharmas are truly not created by me, sentient beings, a life-force, a person, or others. They are neither permanent nor severed.
If they are not created by sentient beings, a life-force, or a person, this is called emptiness.
As they are empty, they are without self, sentient beings, a life-force, and a person. They are impermanent and not severed;
if they are impermanent and not severed, they are unborn and unceasing;
if they are unborn and unceasing, they are not subsumed within the three times;
if they are not subsumed within the three times, they are called non-existent;
if they are non-existent, they cannot be counted;

If one contemplates and thinks, then due to evil causes and conditions, ignorance arises up to the great mass of suffering;

Having contemplated in this way, one does not adhere to the view of permanence or the view of annihilation, knowing that all dharmas arise from conditions and cease due to conditions, knowing that all dharmas are devoid of self, sentient beings, life, and person, and do not see this, that, or the middle.

Furthermore, Jewel Woman!

When bodhisattvas cultivate the path to enlightenment, all physical actions follow the practice of wisdom, not deceiving sentient beings and creating obstacles, not greedy or stingy, having no harmful mind, pure in spiritual practice, diligently cultivating vigor, gathering the causes and conditions for enlightenment without sparing one's life, and giving rise to great compassion for all sentient beings.
